p.content: Nominal phrases can be very complex. This section concentrates on those with common nouns as the lexical head. Modification by articles, demonstratives, possessors, quantifiers and degree words, adjective phrases, pre/post-positional phrases and noun compounds is considered. Participles are also covered, but nominal phrases headed by proper names are handled in section
and those headed by pronouns, demonstratives, and quantifiers are handled in section
. Relative clauses are covered in section
The basic order of elements allowed in nominal phrases in
is:
Each of these phrases will be discussed and exemplified in sections
, after first dealing with agreement and case marking.

Many languages require agreement between at least some of the modifiers and the head noun. While English only has number agreement, in other languages this agreement may also include animacy, class, or gender.
In

case.caseText: there is no number agreement. Instead, number marking comes from the number or quantifier.
the various nominal modifiers may/must agree in number with the head noun.

p.content: Further,

case.caseText: there is no agreement in animacy, class number, nor gender between the modifiers and the head noun.
the modifiers and the head noun may/must agree in animacy.
the modifiers and the head noun may/must agree in class number.
the modifiers and the head noun may/must agree in gender.

p.content: Nouns and their modifiers may also be marked for case. The most common case system is nominative-accusative. This is the system English has, though only pronouns are marked for case in English. In a nominative-accusative system, subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs are in nominative case, while direct objects are accusative case. Possessors are genitive case. The nominative pronouns in English are:
p.langData: I, we, you, he, she, they
p.content: . The accusative pronouns are:
p.langData: me, us, you, him, her, them
p.content: . The genitive pronouns include:
p.langData: my, our, your, his, her, their
p.content: . Therefore, we say
and not

In an ergative-absolutive case system, subjects of transitive verbs are marked with the ergative case, while objects of transitive verbs and subjects of intransitive verbs are marked with the absolutive case. The case of possessors is not set cross-linguistically. Some languages with an ergative-absolutive system simply have different sets of verbal agreement markers, but no marking on nouns. This type of agreement marking will be handled in section

Some languages are even more complex in that they normally have a nominative-accusative system but under some conditions the case system switches to ergative-absolutive. This is called "split ergativity".

case.caseText: does not have any case system. The exact same set of pronouns may be used in any position in the sentence and there is no marking on nouns or on any noun modifiers based on their position in the sentence.

has a nominative-accusative case system. Subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs are marked in the same way and use the same set of pronouns, but objects of transitive verbs are marked differently.

has an ergative-absolutive case system. Subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs are marked in the same way and use the same set of pronouns, but subjects of transitive verbs are marked differently.
has a split case system. The language normally follows the nominative-accusative case system, but the ergative-absolutive system is used under certain conditions.

text.content: Nominative case is the default (unmarked) case.

p.content: The pronoun sets will be given in section

, and
. These were discussed in section
. To review the facts for

text.content: these are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase, so they will not have a position in the phrase structure. Instead, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase.
these are expressed as separate words which occur

after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

text.content: the rest of the nominal phrase.
the positive special degree elements are expressed as separate words which occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

text.content: the rest of the nominal phrase. The negative special degree elements, however, are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase, so they will not have a place in the phrase structure. Instead, they attach to another word in the nominal phrase.
the negative special degree elements are expressed as separate words which occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

text.content: the rest of the nominal phrase. The positive special degree elements, however, are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase, so they will not have a place in the phrase structure. Instead, they attach to another word in the nominal phrase.

p.content: Examples of the positive special degree words in nominal phrases include:
Examples of the negative special degree elements in nominal phrases include:
In English, the articles are
, and
. English demonstratives include
, and
. Some simple examples are:
p.langData: a book, an apple, the book, the books, this apple
p.content: and

In English, articles and demonstratives do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase, and both occur before the noun. Some languages allow both to co-occur in the same phrase, and they may occur in different positions with respect to the noun. Therefore, they need distinct syntactic categories. Some languages only have one set, either articles or demonstratives. A few languages may not have either type expressed as separate words.

case.caseText: does not have either articles or demonstratives that are realized as separate words.
has only articles that are realized as separate words, no demonstratives.
has only demonstratives that are realized as separate words, no articles.
has both articles and demonstratives that are realized as separate words.

text.content: The

case.caseText: articles
demonstratives
articles and demonstratives

text.content: are
not
marked for case.

p.content: The article occurs

case.caseText: before
after
on either side of

p.content: the noun.

text.content: All of the articles may appear on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of the articles may appear on either side of the noun.

p.content: The presence of an article is

case.caseText: always optional.
optional with plural or mass nouns, but is required with singular nouns.
always required.

text.content: In the singular forms, an article is required

case.caseText: before the noun and one may also optionally appear after the noun.
after the noun and one may also optionally appear before the noun.
to appear both before and after the noun.

text.content: An article is required to appear

case.caseText: before the noun and one may also optionally appear after the noun.
after the noun and one may also optionally appear before the noun.
both before and after the noun.

case.caseText: before
after
on either side of

p.content: the noun.

text.content: All of the demonstratives may appear on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of the demonstratives may appear on either side of the noun.

p.content: The presence of a demonstrative is

case.caseText: always optional.
optional with plural or mass nouns, but is required with singular nouns.
always required.

text.content: In the singular forms, a demonstrative is required

case.caseText: before the noun and one may also optionally appear after the noun.
after the noun and one may also optionally appear before the noun.
to appear both before and after the noun.

text.content: A demonstrative is required to appear

case.caseText: before the noun and one may also optionally appear after the noun.
after the noun and one may also optionally appear before the noun.
both before and after the noun.

p.content: The articles and demonstratives both appear in the same position, so they do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase. Articles or demonstratives appear

case.caseText: before
after
on either side of

p.content: the noun.

text.content: All of the articles and demonstratives may appear on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of the articles and demonstratives may appear on either side of the noun.

case.caseText: always optional.
optional with plural or mass nouns, but is required with singular nouns.
always required.

case.caseText: before the noun and one may also optionally appear after the noun.
after the noun and one may also optionally appear before the noun.
to appear both before and after the noun.

case.caseText: before the noun and one may also optionally appear after the noun.
after the noun and one may also optionally appear before the noun.
both before and after the noun.

case.caseText: but both may not
and both may

p.content: Examples of nominal phrases including articles and/or demonstratives as allowed in
include:
Possession can normally be expressed by a possessive pronoun (to be addressed in section
) or by a full nominal phrase. Many languages also add some kind of marking, such as the

in English, as an indication of possession. These markings are either affixes (or clitics) on the head noun or phrase-level clitics which attach to one end of the whole phrase. The English marking is this second type, because alongside phrases where the
appears to attach to the head noun, as in
, there are phrases which clearly show that the clitic attaches to the end of the whole nominal phrase, such as
p.langData: the boy that I just talked to's mother
p.content: or
p.langData: the girl in green's wonderful speech
p.content: . Possessors can also be embedded in one another, as in
Examples of possessed nominal phrases with simple and embedded possessors in
include:
Examples with pre/post-positional phrases within the possessor include:
Examples with relative clauses within the possessor here, included in simple full sentences are:
As seen in the examples above,

case.caseText: does not have any special marking to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.
marks the head noun within the possessor with an affix to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.
marks the whole possessive phrase with a phrasal clitic to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.

text.content: This phrasal clitic is an enclitic which attaches to the final word in the possessor.
This phrasal clitic is an proclitic which attaches to the first word in the possessor.
This phrasal clitic is written as a separate word which occurs

case.caseText: before
after

text.content: the possessor. The possessive clitic is

case.caseText: optional in some cases.
always required.

p.content: The possessor occurs

case.caseText: before
after
on either side of

p.content: the noun being possessed.

section3.secTitle: Possessors and Articles Or Demonstratives Occuring Together

p.content: In English, possessors and articles or demonstratives do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase, unless the possessor is expressed in a prepositional phrase. For example,
is ungrammatical; instead one would use
to express the same thought. Some other languages allow both possessors and articles or demonstratives to occur in the same phrase, so the first example above would be grammatical.
In
, nominal possessors

case.caseText: may
may not

p.content: occur in the same phrase as articles or demonstratives.
With the normal nominative-accusative case system followed by
, possessors are marked with the genitive case.
Possessors in
are marked with the genitive case, following the normal nominative-accusative part of the split case system. In the parts which display split ergativity, possessors are marked with the

case.caseText: ergative case, the same marking as the subjects of transitive verbs.
absolutive case, the same marking as the subjects of intransitive verbs and the objects of transitive verbs.
genitive case also.

p.content: Within the ergative-absolutive case system followed by
, possessors are marked with the

case.caseText: ergative case, the same marking as the subjects of transitive verbs.
absolutive case, the same marking as the subjects of intransitive verbs and the objects of transitive verbs.
genitive case, a distinct marking for possessors.

p.content: In some languages, in a possessed noun phrase the head noun and any modifiers matches the case of the possessor. In other languages, the possessor is marked with its own case, say genitive, while the head noun is marked with case depending on its position relative to the verb: nominative or accusative, ergative or absolutive depending on the case system.
In

case.caseText: the grammatical function of the head noun relative to the verb determines its case, not the presence of a possessor.
the case of the head noun matches the case of the possessor, when a possessor is present.

p.content: Possessor agreement normally comes in two basic forms:

li.content: An affix that occurs on alienably possessed nouns to indicate that they are possessed and therefore must have a possessor in the nominal phrase. Inalienably possessed nouns do not take any marking, but must always have a possessor. These include, but are not limited to, kinship terms and body parts.
An affix that agrees with the possessor (or possibly expresses the possessor by itself).

case.caseText: does not distinguish
does make a distinction

p.content: between alienably and inalienably possessed nouns.

text.content: The affix which marks alienably possessed nouns when they have a possessor is:

p.content: In
, nouns

case.caseText: are not
are

p.content: marked with an affix which either agrees with the possessor or expresses the possessor by itself.

text.content: These affixes mark the following features of the possessor:

p.content: Quantifier phrases (QP) were discussed earlier in section
. Such modifiers mark the number of the whole nominal phrase. English examples of quantified nominal phrases include:
and
p.langData: only the first one hundred boys
p.content: . All the quantifier phrases occur before the noun in English.
In
, quantifier phrases occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the noun.

text.content: All of quantifier phrases can occur on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of the quantifier phrases can occur on each side of the noun.
All of the numbers occur before the noun.
All of the numbers occur after the noun.

p.content: examples of quantified nominal phrases include:
Like other modifiers within the nominal phrase, quantifier phrases in
show agreement with the head noun in

case.caseText: animacy.
class number.
gender.

p.content: Adjective phrases (AdjP) were discussed earlier in section
. Adjective phrases occur close to the noun, yielding nominal phrases such as:
p.langData: just those very few old, dirty books
all the boy’s many black dogs
p.content: and
p.langData: only the first one hundred very eager young boys
p.content: . As the English examples show, adjectives all occur before the noun, and more than one adjective phrase is allowed. This is handled by a recursive rule.
In
, adjective phrases occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the noun.

text.content: All of the adjective phrases can occur on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of the adjective phrases can occur on each side of the noun.

p.content: examples of nominal phrases which are modified by qualitative adjectives include:
Like other modifiers within the nominal phrase, adjective phrases in
show agreement with the head noun in

case.caseText: animacy.
class number.
gender.

p.content: Participles or participle phrases may also act as adjectives in modifying a noun. Some English examples with the participle or participle phrase bracketed include:
and
Examples in
include:

section3.secTitle: Case Change with Adjective Phrase Modifiers

p.content: Languages like

which change the case of the head noun when a possessor is present normally also change the case of intervening adjectives to match. Some languages of this type also change the case of the head noun when only an adjectival modifier is present, even when there is no possessor.
In
, the case of the head noun

case.caseText: only changes when a possessor is present, though in that situation an intervening adjective may/must also carry that case.
changes to match the normal case of a possessor even if just an adjectival modifier is present.

p.content: Further, some languages of this latter type have an overt affix which marks the genitive case (or the normal case of possessors) on the head noun to indicate that there must be either an adjective or a possessor in that nominal phrase. In this situation, the adjective and/or possessor will also be in genitive case (or the normal case of possessors), though the case marking will not be overt on the highest modifier in the nominal phrase.
In
, the case marking

case.caseText: is not
is
is

p.content: handled in this distinctive way.

text.content: When the overt
genitive
or
ergative
absolutive

case.caseText: suffix
prefix

text.content: is present on the head noun, it indicates that an adjectival modifier and/or a possessor must be present in the phrase. If the adjective is marked with this
genitive
or
ergative
absolutive

case.caseText: suffix,
prefix,

text.content: then another adjective and/or a possessor must also be present.

p.content: Many languages are like English, in that they have noun modifiers. It may seem like all nouns can also be used as adjectives, but a closer look reveals that true adjectives come before the noun modifier, as in
but not
. Therefore, noun modifiers will be treated as compound nouns which are written as separate words.
In the English examples above,
is clearly the head noun rather than
, because
is restricting the type of
, not the other way around. In all compound nouns and noun modifier constructions in English, the head is the right-most noun in the series.
does not have any compound nouns or noun modifiers that are written as separate words. They are all written as a single word with the head noun. Examples include:
has compound nouns or noun modifiers that are written as separate words. The

case.caseText: left-most
right-most

p.content: noun is the head in these constructions. Examples include:
Both simple and compound nouns may have pre/post-positional phrase (PP) modifiers or complements, such as in
and
. In addition, genitive pre/post-positional phrases may take the place of the possessor, such as
and
. In English, the PP always comes after the noun.
In
, the PP occurs

case.caseText: before
after
on either side of

p.content: the head noun.
examples with PP modifiers or complements include:
See section
for more details on PPs in

Another case which may look like a noun and a complement may actually be a participle phrase (also called a gerund). This whole phrase occupies a normal argument position, such as subject, object, indirect object or the object of a preposition. Some English examples in full sentences with the participle phrase bracketed include:
p.langData: [Studying participles] is challenging, He likes [reading Latin poetry]
p.content: and
p.langData: The receiver showed his worth by [making the catch].
p.content: Such phrases may be possessed or be modified as well, and sometimes only the participle stands alone as the head of a nominal phrase, as in
and
Therefore, our grammar rules will allow participle phrases to occupy the head position in the nominal phrase.
Examples from
of participles or participle phrases that can take the place of a noun in a nominal phrase include:
These participle phrases can be used in full sentences as shown here:
